questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding acute radiation syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Gl manifestations occur at a lower radiation dose than bone marrow depression

options.label: B
options.text: Doses greater than 2 Gy cause hematopoietic syndrome with pancytopenia

options.label: C
options.text: Doses greater than 6 Gy cause GI syndrome with dehydration

options.label: D
options.text: Doses greater than 20 -30 Gy cause Cardiovascular syndrome

questions.correct_answer: A. Gl manifestations occur at a lower radiation dose than bone marrow depression
questions.explanation:
Syndrome

Radiation Dose (Gy)

Clinical Features

Hematopoietic Syndrome

>2 Gy

Pancytopenia, infections, bleeding, anemia

Gastrointestinal Syndrome

>6 Gy

Nausea, vomiting, dehydration, diarrhea, shock

Cardiovascular/CNS Syndrome

>30 Gy

Hypotension, seizures, coma, cardiovascular collapse

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in Rigler's triad, as observed in a middle-aged female patient with a past medical history of cholelithiasis, who presented with symptoms of vomiting and abdominal pain, and whose abdominal radiograph revealed Rigler's triad?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D.

questions.text: What investigation is depicted in the radiograph among the following options?
What is the cause of the appearance observed in IVP?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option b: Ureterococele.

Definition Ureterocele is a congenital or acquired condition where the ureter (the tube that carries urine from the kidney to the bladder) balloons at its lower end, forming a pouch-like structure.
Types Primary (congenital) and secondary (acquired) ureteroceles. Primary ureteroceles are typically present from birth and occur as a result of abnormal embryonic development. Secondary ureteroceles may develop later in life due to various factors.
Location Most commonly found in the ureter that drains one kidney, but bilateral ureteroceles (affecting both kidneys) can occur in rare cases.
Presentation Ureteroceles can be asymptomatic or cause a range of symptoms, including urinary tract infections (UTIs), flank pain, abdominal discomfort, hematuria (blood in the urine), and difficulty in emptying the bladder.
Diagnosis Typically diagnosed through imaging studies such as ultrasound, intravenous pyelogram (IVP), CT scan, or cystoscopy.
Treatment Treatment depends on the severity of symptoms and complications. Options may include antibiotics for UTIs, surgical removal of the ureterocele, endoscopic procedures, and in some cases, surgery to reconstruct the urinary tract.

questions.text: Personal monitoring of radiation is done by:
questions.explanation:
TLD (Thermoluminescent Dosimeter) Badge

Purpose

It is worn by individuals in radiation-exposed environments, such as medical imaging or nuclear facilities, to track their radiation dose and ensure it stays within safe limits.

Location

Worn beneath the lead apron (as lead apron cuts off some radiation)

Duration

According to the Atomic Energy Regulatory Board (AERB) of India, TLD badges are generally replaced and analyzed every 3 months to assess cumulative radiation exposure.

Composition

Thermoluminescent phosphor crystals:

  • Calcium sulfate dysprosium
  • Lithium fluoride
  • Lithium borate
  • Berrylium oxide

Principle

questions.text: Which among the following is most radiosensitive?
What type of MRI image is given below?
Identify the imaging modality given below.
questions.explanation:
Ultrasound Gel

Purpose of Gel
  • Eliminates air pockets between probe and skin for effective sound transmission.
  • Serves as a medium for sound and lubricant.

Preferred Gel
  • Hydrogel is preferred over Lipogel for easier cleaning.

Ingredients
  • Distilled water, carbomer, ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA), propylene glycol, glycerin, trolamine, and occasionally contains blue colorant.

Infection Control

Cover transducer and skin with plastic for patients with open wounds or skin issues.

↓

Apply gel on both sides of the plastic.

↓

Clean transducer after each use

Types of Ultrasound Transducers/ Probes

Linear
  • Shape: Rectangular/parallelogram image
  • Use: Vascular, high-resolution imaging

Convex
  • Shape: Sector image, curved top
  • Use: Abdominal, OBS/ GYN

Phased Array
  • Shape: Sector image, pointed top
  • Use: Cardiac (fits between ribs), endocavitary (like endovaginal), neonatal brain

Vector/ Trapezoidal
  • Shape: Trapezoidal image
  • Use: Abdominal, cardiac, Doppler
  • Features: Hybrid of linear & phased

questions.text: The magnetic field in MRI machines is measured in which of the following units?
questions.explanation:
Unit

Symbol

Measurement Type

Application

Tesla

T

Magnetic field strength

Used in MRI to measure magnetic field intensity (e.g., 1.5T, 3T, 7T MRI scanners)

Gauss

G

Magnetic field strength

Older unit for magnetic field strength (1T = 10,000G)

Gray

Gy

Absorbed dose of radiation

Measures energy absorbed per unit mass in radiotherapy

Sievert

Sv

Biological effect of radiation

Used in radiation safety to assess exposure risk

Hounsfield Unit

HU

Tissue density in CT

Used in CT scans to differentiate tissues (e.g., bone = +1000 HU, air = -1000 HU)

Becquerel

Bq

Radioactive decay rate

Used in nuclear medicine to measure radioactivity

Curie

Ci

Radioactivity

Older unit (1 Ci = 3.7 × 10¹⁰ Bq), used in nuclear imaging

Roentgen

R

Ionization in air

Used in older radiation exposure measurements

Millisievert

mSv

Radiation dose

Used for radiation protection, CT scan doses are often measured in mSv

Electron Volt

eV

Energy of X-rays/Gamma rays

Used in radiation physics to measure photon energy

Kiloelectron Volt

keV

X-ray photon energy

Important in X-ray and CT imaging for beam quality

questions.text: Ga-68 PSMA PET scan is used to diagnose which of the following conditions?
During the procedure shown below which one of the following substances is uptaken by the cancer cells?
questions.explanation:
Mechanism

Description

Aerobic Glycolysis

Cancer cells rely heavily on glycolysis, increasing glucose and 18F-FDG uptake, even with oxygen.

Transport & Trapping

GLUT-1 transporters mediate glucose entry. 18F-FDG is phosphorylated and trapped inside cells.

Tumor Heterogeneity

Differences in tumor subtype, size, and microvasculature affect 18F-FDG uptake.

Implication

Details

Prognostic Indicator

Higher 18F-FDG uptake correlates with worse prognosis (e.g., shorter DFS in invasive ductal carcinoma).

Reverse Warburg Effect

Cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) increase glycolysis in tumor cells via metabolic coupling.

Treatment Monitoring

PET imaging tracks changes in 18F-FDG uptake, reflecting therapy responses targeting glycolysis or mitochondria.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient presents with complaints of abdominal pain; further investigations show elevated PTH levels and renal calculi. Which of the following investigations should be done next?
questions.explanation:
Hyperparathyroidism

Functions of the parathyroid gland
  • Increase the level of calcium in the body (Subperiosteal bone resorption).
  • Decrease the level of phosphorus in the body (Urinary excretion of phosphorus).

Types

  • Primary hyperparathyroidism (parathyroid adenoma and parathyroid hyperplasia)
  • Secondary hyperparathyroidism

Radiological features

  • Subperiosteal resorption usually starts in the middle phalanx of the index finger's radial side, leading to a concavity of bone (the earliest bone change).
  • The "salt and pepper" appearance, or pepper pot skull (lytic lesions in the skull).
  • Brown tumor or osteitis fibrosa cystica: Cystic lesions resulting from excessive osteoclastic resorption appear as low-density, multiloculated cysts that can cause bone expansion, often accompanied by hemorrhage and granulation tissue (more common in primary hyperparathyroidism).

 

  • Rugger jersey spine: Characterized by alternating black and white striations, with sclerosed white end plates and black vertebral bodies; commonly seen in renal osteodystrophy (secondary hyperparathyroidism).

FAST Scan Findings

Description

Negative FAST

Equivocal FAST

questions.text: Which of the subsequent investigations operate based on the same principle?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B

Radiological Investigation

Principle

X-ray

Ionizing radiation is passed through the body, and the resulting image is captured on a detector.

Computed Tomography (CT)

X-ray beams rotate around the body, and multiple cross-sectional images are generated and reconstructed by a computer.

Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)

Powerful magnetic fields and radio waves are used to create detailed images of the body's structures based on the behavior of hydrogen atoms in the body.

Ultrasound (USG)

High-frequency sound waves are emitted and their reflections are used to create real-time images of the internal organs.

Positron Emission Tomography (PET)

A radioactive tracer is injected into the body, and its distribution and metabolism are detected to visualize the functioning of organs and tissues.

Single-Photon Emission Computed Tomography (SPECT)

A radioactive tracer is injected into the body, and the emitted gamma rays are detected to create three-dimensional images.

Mammography

Low-dose X-rays are used to image the breast tissue, primarily for breast cancer screening and diagnosis.

Fluoroscopy

Continuous X-ray beams are used to create real-time moving images of the internal structures, such as the digestive or respiratory systems.

Bone Densitometry

X-rays or ultrasound are used to measure the density of bones, helping diagnose osteoporosis and assess fracture risk.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of ionizing radiation?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Principles of MRI: Understand the basic principles underlying MRI, including nuclear magnetic resonance, the precession of hydrogen atoms, and the generation of a magnetic resonance signal. MRI Machine Components: Familiarize yourself with the components of an MRI machine, such as the main magnet, gradient coils, radiofrequency coils, and the computer system. Image Acquisition: Learn about the process of image acquisition in MRI, including data acquisition, pulse sequences, and the use of gradient fields to encode spatial information. Image Contrast: Understand the different types of image contrast in MRI, including T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and proton density-weighted images, and how they are influenced by the relaxation times of tissues. MRI Safety: Be aware of the safety considerations in MRI, including the potential risks associated with the strong magnetic field, radiofrequency energy, and the use of contrast agents. Understand the screening process for patients and the safety guidelines for staff. Clinical Applications: Explore the wide range of clinical applications of MRI, including imaging of the brain, spine, musculoskeletal system, abdomen, pelvis, and cardiovascular system. Understand the strengths and limitations of MRI compared to other imaging modalities. Contrast Agents: Learn about the use of contrast agents in MRI, such as gadolinium-based agents, for enhancing the visualization of certain tissues and pathologies. Advanced MRI Techniques: Gain knowledge of advanced MRI techniques, such as diffusion-weighted imaging, perfusion imaging, functional MRI (fMRI), spectroscopy, and diffusion tensor imaging (DTI). Artifacts: Understand common artifacts that can occur in MRI images, their causes, and strategies to minimize or correct them.
  • ➤ Principles of MRI: Understand the basic principles underlying MRI, including nuclear magnetic resonance, the precession of hydrogen atoms, and the generation of a magnetic resonance signal.
  • ➤ MRI Machine Components: Familiarize yourself with the components of an MRI machine, such as the main magnet, gradient coils, radiofrequency coils, and the computer system.
  • ➤ Image Acquisition: Learn about the process of image acquisition in MRI, including data acquisition, pulse sequences, and the use of gradient fields to encode spatial information.
  • ➤ Image Contrast: Understand the different types of image contrast in MRI, including T1-weighted, T2-weighted, and proton density-weighted images, and how they are influenced by the relaxation times of tissues.
  • ➤ MRI Safety: Be aware of the safety considerations in MRI, including the potential risks associated with the strong magnetic field, radiofrequency energy, and the use of contrast agents. Understand the screening process for patients and the safety guidelines for staff.
  • ➤ Clinical Applications: Explore the wide range of clinical applications of MRI, including imaging of the brain, spine, musculoskeletal system, abdomen, pelvis, and cardiovascular system. Understand the strengths and limitations of MRI compared to other imaging modalities.
  • ➤ Contrast Agents: Learn about the use of contrast agents in MRI, such as gadolinium-based agents, for enhancing the visualization of certain tissues and pathologies.
  • ➤ Advanced MRI Techniques: Gain knowledge of advanced MRI techniques, such as diffusion-weighted imaging, perfusion imaging, functional MRI (fMRI), spectroscopy, and diffusion tensor imaging (DTI).
  • ➤ Artifacts: Understand common artifacts that can occur in MRI images, their causes, and strategies to minimize or correct them.
